CalcFutureAmount Function:
int CalcFutureAmount(Double StartAmount, double AnnualInterest, double Years){
int FutureAmountl 0
double FutureAmountD = 0.00
double Decimallnterest =
Annuallnterest/100n FutureAmountD =
StartAmount (Math.pow(1+DecimalInterest), Years))
 FutureAmountl = (int)FutureAmountD
return FutureAmountl
}

salesNetD (salesPriceD - (sales PriceD - (salesPriceD/(1 +(vatPercentD) / 100)))
grossProfitD = (salesNetD - costPriceD)
markupPercentD ((sales NetD - costPriceD) / costPriceD) *100)
marginPercentD (salesNetD - costPriceD) / salesNetD)* 100

Informed by:
http://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/102714/whats -difference-between-profit-margin-and-markup.asp

salesNetPriceD (costPriceD + (costPriceD* (markupPercentD/ 100))
vatD salesNetPriceD * (vatPercentD/100)
marginPercentD (salesNetPriceD - costPriceD) salesNetPriceD) * 100
grossProfitPercentD = (salesNetPriceD - costPriceD)
salesGrossPriceD (salesNetPriceD + vatD) Informed by:
http://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/102714/whats -difference-between-profit-margin-and-markup.asp

grossProfitD = salesD - costOfSalesD
grossProfitPercentD = (grossProfitD/ salesD) * 100
expensesTotalD = expensesD +depreciationD + interestChargesD
operatingProfitD (grossProfitD - (expensesD + depreciationD))
 operatingProfitPercentD (operatingProfitD / salesD) * 100
netProfitD = grossProfitD expenses TotalD
netProfitPercentD (netProfitD / salesD) * 100
cashGenerationD = (grossProfitD expensesD)
breakevenSalesD = (expensesTotalD / (grossProfitPercentD/ 100))
 breakevenSales PercentD = (breakevenSalesD / salesD) *100)
breakevenDays D = (breakevenSalesD/ (salesD / 365)

vat1D ((salesNetPrice1D) * (vatPercent 1 D/ 100);
salesGrossPrice1 D = salesNetPrice1D + vat1D

stage1Convert PercentD= (salesstage1D/salesstage1D)*100
 stage2ConvertPercentD= (salesstage2D/salesstage1 D)*100
 stage3Convert PercentD= (salesstage3D/salesstage 1D)*100
 stage4Convert PercentD= (salesstage4D/salesstage1 D)*100
 actualBuyersConvert PercentD= (actualbuyers D/salesstage 1D)*100
 targetStage1D=(targetbuyersD/(actualBuyers Convert PercentD/100))
 targetStage2D= (targetStage1 D*(stage2ConvertPercentD/100))
 targetStage3D= (targetStage1 D (stage3Convert PercentD/100))
 targetStage4D= (targetStage1D*(stage4ConvertPercentD/100))
 targetBuyersCalcD=(targetStage1D*(actualBuyersConvertPercentD/100))

The helpful summary of funnel analysis in Wikipedia and the article referenced
Jansen, B. J. and Schuster, S. (2011) Bidding on the Buying Funnel for Sponsored Search Campaigns, Journal of Electronic Commerce Research. 12(1), 1-18 Also helpful summaries and examples calculations at:

https://blog.udemy.com/sales-funnel/

Cost of Sales must be required!
Customer Days Credit must be required!
Supplier Days Credit must be required!
Probably a VALID Contract, but may be hard to enforce
Probably a VALID Contract that is enforceable
Sales Net Price must be required!
Sales Gross Price must be required!

A narrow geographic market can be a successful market position for a small business. This is especially the case if there are opportunities to customize product or services to the specific needs of the local market. Larger businesses can find local knowledge difficult to obtain and the cost of adapting to the local market prohibitive.Targetting specific customers can be a successful strategyfor small businesses. It can allow them to adapt their products or services so they are better suited to the needs of their targetted customers. The internet has provided the opportunity for small scale firms to customise their products and services to very focused customer niches and then to service wide geographic areas. Large firms can find it hard to adapt their product and services to very focused customer segments.\n\n

Offering few products or services can be successful strategy for small businesses Having a small range allows them to customize their products and services to particular customers and local markets. Larger firms are less likely to be so focused and may find it hard to compete.\n\n

Providing goods or services of a similar quality to competitors at a lower price ca in some circumstances be successful for small businesses. Larger businesses are often better suited to competing on price to a broad market as they can achieve lower costs through scale. However, sma firms maybe able to compete on price where they adapt there product or service to a particular customer segment or geographic area that has been ignored by larger firms. Also opportunities may existfor small firms where labour costs are lov or transportation costs are high.

Targetting specific customers can be a successful strategy for small businesses It can allow them to adapt their products or services so they are better suited to the needs of their targetted customers.The internet has provided the opportunity for small scale firms to customise their products and services to very focused customer niches and then to service wide geographic areas. Large firms can find it hard to adapt their product and services to very focused customer segments.\n\n

A combination of wide geographic market and trying to sell to everyone is less likely to be a successful strategy for small firms. Large firms are better suited to selling to such customers as they can achieve lower costs from their scale. Small firms are better suited to customising their products or services to suit specific customers or a particular narrow geographic area.\n
Cost of Sales Credit must be required!
